awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   Assessing the Effects of Tourism Development on Small-Scale Fisheries
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will analyze how the expansion of tourism into rural coastal regions is changing the dynamics of human-environment interactions and livelihoods related to small-scale fisheries. Overlooked for decades due to their small and informal nature, small-scale fisheries have increasingly garnered attention as their socio-economic importance and ecological impact is better understood. In rural coastal ecosystems, small-scale fisheries are often a primary source of livelihoods, protein, and micronutrients for local populations and can be the dominant form of marine resource-use. Globally they account for up to a third of global fisheries catches, and provide 50% of the seafood caught for human consumption. Small-scale fisheries are disproportionately concentrated in lower-income regions where their importance to coastal communities is amplified by isolation and poverty, and high resource dependence and limited environmental management make ecosystems vulnerable to over exploitation. In many of these areas tourism is viewed as a pathway for sustainable development, with the hope that new livelihood opportunities will elevate the socioeconomic wellbeing of the community and reduce pressure on natural resources. Despite the potential for such development, research increasingly shows that the socio-economic and ecological implications of these livelihood transitions vary widely, creating a disconnect between conservation and development planning and actual social and environmental outcomes. Understanding the mechanisms of how tourism affects coastal socio-ecological systems will enable governments, managers, and communities to anticipate the positive and negative impacts of tourism development, and be more prepared to strategically mitigate or counteract the negative aspects. The project will also contribute to the training of a doctoral student.

This research will investigate how the availability of alternative livelihoods changes fishing behavior; how the influx of tourists changes the demand for and local consumption of seafood; and how these changes affect community and household socio-economic status and food security and impact marine resources. Although this research project will focus on a case study in Colombia, the research will provide new insights and approaches for dealing with tourism's impacts in many other countries, including the United States. The research will be conducted in eight communities on the Pacific Coast of Colombia that are being transformed through tourism development. These communities share similar sociocultural heritage and exist within a connected ecosystem, but differ in the extent and nature of tourism development, allowing for a side-by-side comparison of the livelihood transition and social and ecological consequences of tourism development. Interviews, observation, and archival research will be used to build upon previous fieldwork in order to contextualize, clarify, and probe the causality of relationships that emerged in the analysis of quantitative household surveys.

por.por_cntn:
This study investigated the socio-ecological interactions between tourism development and small-scale fisheries in rural coastal regions, seeking to better understand how tourism impacts fishing behavior, seafood consumption, and food security. Small-scale fisheries are disproportionately concentrated in rural areas and developing countries where they are often the dominant form of marine resource-use, the primary source of animal protein, and provide livelihoods to over 200 million people. Globally, small-scale fisheries supply nearly 50% of seafood for human consumption and account for up to a third of global fisheries catches. Tourism, on the other hand, is one of the largest economic sectors in the world, is concentrated in coastal areas, and is growing fastest in developing markets (UNWTO 2017). Thus, fishing and tourism are two of the most important economic activities in coastal areas around the world, yet little is known about how they interact and how tourism impacts small-scale fisheries.  

In this project, these interactions and impacts were studied in eight coastal communities undergoing tourism development on the Pacific Coast of Colombia. Tourism development was found to have no consistent impact on fishing effort, but to significantly change the nature of the fishery and its role in the community. Relative to communities without tourism, fisheries in communities with more tourism development were smaller and more professional, with intensified effort, a higher ratio of catches destined for market, and a growing concentration of capital among middlemen who rent gear and buy the catches. Within the community, these changes are reflected in local diets and food security. As fewer people participate in the fishery, less food is locally produced and more of their diets come from imported food goods. This increases the overall availability and diversity of food goods, leading to an increase in food security by some measures, however as economic inequality also rises, some lower-income households experience a new dimension of food insecurity if they cannot afford the cost of imported foods. 

Comparing between communities also shed light on what factors contribute to variation in impact, including the type and timing of development and the presence of effective local governance before tourism development. Slower, smaller-scale development allows households more time to adapt to the new opportunities and challenges, and more time for local governance to take an active role in development. Where development is community-led or has high local ownership of tourism operations, the benefits are more widely distributed among households and community-wide improvements (e.g. infrastructure and public services) are more likely. Alternatively, where tourism development is driven by outside investment, many of the benefits of tourism leave the community or are concentrated among a local elite, leading to growing inequality and increased vulnerability for some households. Communities with prior exposure to tourism, usually via tourism development in a neighboring community, also had more experience to inform these development decisions and increased the likelihood that tourism would be beneficial for local households. Regardless of the type of development occurring, the presence and strength of local governance is critical in minimizing negative impacts. Additionally, nature-based tourism can incentivize locally led conservation initiatives in the coastal and marine environments, but this effect was only visible when the attractions were specifically related to biodiversity and environmental health (e.g. bird watching).

Findings from this research can be used to inform best practices in coastal tourism development and adaptive resource management and been/will be shared with diverse audiences through conferences, academic publications, and direct outreach to practitioners. These efforts to expand our understanding of how coastal tourism development impacts communities and fisheries can benefit US-funded development programs, such as those supported by USAID, as well as other government and NGO-funded programs that seek to improve the natural resource management and/or quality of life in coastal regions. Results of the research have been shared with the communities and government agencies overseeing conservation and development in the study region, and also with international, government, and NGO partners in Colombia through a working group on socio-ecological connectivity to inform their approach to integrated coastal planning projects that are underway in the Caribbean region.
